subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Utter/Ado
msgSnippet: ... The trouble is, of course, the large and growing number of people for whom LOT = CLOTH = THOUGHT = PALM.  Shall we go down from two letters to only one?
messageBody:
Benct Philip Jonsson scripsit:

> Wells also makes a good case for not distinguishing the lexical sets
> TRAP-FATHER-BATH (At-Ah in QS terminology) or LOT-THOUGHT-CLOTH (QS
> Ox-Awe). For all Read's genius when it came to Utter-and-Ado he seems
> to have been overly home- blind and maximist concerning these lexical
> sets. I find Awe and Ah cumbersome to write, and would not shed a tear
> if they were abolished, or used only to write foreign names.

The trouble is, of course, the large and growing number of people for
whom LOT = CLOTH = THOUGHT = PALM. Shall we go down from two letters
to only one? That seems much too minimalist to me, but doing anything
else continues to involve us in arbitrary distinctions.

(While I'm at it, I should apologize for assuming that everybody elides
/l/ in "palm" and similar words. Clearly not true, although in my
four-person five-accent household only one of us fails to elide it.)

> That's exactly the problem with TO, which not only persists in making
> distinctions that were lost before Shakespeare, or already in Latin
> or Old French in the case of loanwords,

The real problem is the spellings that have become completely randomized
with time, that are predictable by no rule however complicated (aka
"maggelitous"). Fix all of those, and we would get a long way to rational
Inglish, as Axel Wijk demonstrated.

--
In my last lifetime, John Cowan
I believed in reincarnation; http://www.ccil.org/~cowan
in this lifetime, cowan@...
I don't. --Thiagi
